section.title: The void type
section.para: The void type is a special type that has no values. (Aside: An alternative would be to view void that only a single value, null, the zero-length sequence. That is more flexible, but it seems more useful to be able to have a compile-error when assigning a void expression to a variable, say.) Semantically, a statement is essentially an expression whose type is void. (Syntactically it may not be quite that. ???)

section.title: The unreachable type
section.para: The unreachable type is a special type used for an expression that never returns a value to its encloding expression. For example, a ReturnExpression has type unreachable because execution continues at the surrounding function's call-site.
